questions.q: What is the chemical symbol for Gold?
questions.explanation: Au comes from the Latin 'aurum' meaning gold.

questions.q: What is the atomic number of Carbon?
questions.explanation: Carbon has 6 protons. Atomic number = number of protons.

questions.q: Which element has the symbol 'Fe'?
questions.explanation: Fe comes from the Latin 'ferrum'.

questions.q: What group do Helium, Neon, and Argon belong to?
questions.explanation: Noble gases (Group 18) have full outer electron shells.

questions.q: Which element is the most abundant in Earth's atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of the atmosphere.

questions.q: What is the atomic number of Oxygen?
questions.explanation: Oxygen has 8 protons.

questions.q: Which element has the highest electronegativity?
questions.explanation: Fluorine (3.98) is the most electronegative element on the Pauling scale.

questions.q: What is the lightest element?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen has an atomic mass of ~1.008 u.

sections.name: Chemical Reactions

scenarios.passage: In an exothermic reaction, energy is released to the surroundings, usually as heat. The products have less energy than the reactants. The enthalpy change (ΔH) is negative. Common examples include combustion (burning fuel), neutralization (acid + base), and rusting of iron. In contrast, endothermic reactions absorb energy — the products have more energy than the reactants, and ΔH is positive. Photosynthesis and melting ice are endothermic.

questions.q: In an exothermic reaction, the enthalpy change (ΔH) is:
questions.explanation: Energy leaves the system → ΔH < 0.

questions.q: Which is an example of an endothermic process?
questions.explanation: Melting absorbs heat from surroundings.

questions.q: In an exothermic reaction, the products have:
questions.explanation: Energy was released, so products are lower energy.

questions.q: Photosynthesis is classified as:
questions.explanation: Plants absorb light energy to build glucose.

scenarios.passage: Balancing chemical equations follows the Law of Conservation of Mass: atoms are neither created nor destroyed. The number of each type of atom must be equal on both sides. Steps: (1) Write the unbalanced equation. (2) Count atoms on each side. (3) Add coefficients (not subscripts) to balance. (4) Check your work. Example: H₂ + O₂ → H₂O becomes 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O.

questions.q: What law requires balancing chemical equations?
questions.explanation: Mass is conserved — atoms in = atoms out.

questions.q: When balancing equations, you adjust:
questions.explanation: Changing subscripts would change the substance itself.

questions.q: In 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, how many oxygen atoms are on each side?
questions.explanation: O₂ has 2 oxygen atoms. 2H₂O also has 2 oxygen atoms.

tips: Always check that atom counts match on both sides
Balance metals first, then nonmetals, then hydrogen, then oxygen
Coefficients multiply ALL atoms in a formula
Never change subscripts to balance — only coefficients

questions.q: What type of bond forms between a metal and a nonmetal?
questions.explanation: Metals lose electrons, nonmetals gain them → ionic bond.

questions.q: In a covalent bond, electrons are:
wrong: Transferred from one atom to another
questions.explanation: Covalent = co-valence = sharing electrons.

questions.q: What is the shape of a methane (CH₄) molecule?
questions.explanation: 4 bonding pairs around carbon → tetrahedral (109.5°).

questions.q: Which type of intermolecular force is the weakest?
questions.explanation: London forces are temporary induced dipoles — weakest IMF.

questions.q: A polar molecule has:
questions.correct: An uneven distribution of electron density
questions.explanation: Polar = asymmetric charge distribution.

questions.q: How many covalent bonds does Nitrogen typically form?
questions.explanation: N has 5 valence electrons, needs 3 more → 3 bonds.

glossary.def: Smallest unit of an element that retains its chemical properties. Made of protons, neutrons, electrons.
Two or more atoms bonded together. Can be same element (O₂) or different (H₂O).
Atom or molecule with a net electric charge due to gaining or losing electrons.
Positively charged ion (lost electrons). Example: Na⁺.
Negatively charged ion (gained electrons). Example: Cl⁻.
Atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons. Same atomic #, different mass.
Tendency of an atom to attract shared electrons in a bond. F is highest (3.98).
Electrons in the outermost shell. Determine bonding behavior and chemical properties.
Bond formed by transfer of electrons from metal to nonmetal. Creates ions held by electrostatic attraction.
Bond formed by sharing electron pairs between nonmetal atoms.
Heat content of a system. Negative ΔH = exothermic, positive ΔH = endothermic.
Reaction that releases energy (heat) to surroundings. ΔH < 0.
Reaction that absorbs energy from surroundings. ΔH > 0.
Substance that speeds up a reaction without being consumed. Lowers activation energy.
6.022 × 10²³ particles (Avogadro's number). Bridges atomic and macroscopic scales.
Quantitative relationships between reactants and products in a balanced equation.
Loss of electrons (or increase in oxidation state). OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss.
Gain of electrons (or decrease in oxidation state). OIL RIG: Reduction Is Gain.
Measure of acidity/basicity. pH < 7 = acidic, pH = 7 = neutral, pH > 7 = basic.
Diagram showing bonding pairs and lone pairs of electrons around atoms in a molecule.
